message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and lab results suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is characterized by irregular menstrual bleeding, elevated luteinizing hormone, and elevated testosterone. Enlarged ovaries can be seen on transvaginal ultrasound, which would further confirm the diagnosis. Elevated serum beta-HCG would suggest pregnancy, adrenal tumor would likely show abnormal levels of aldosterone or cortisol, and an intrasellar mass would suggest a pituitary tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has irregular menstrual bleeding and elevated luteinizing hormone and testosterone levels, indicating polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Enlarged ovaries are a common finding on transvaginal ultrasound in patients with PCOS. Elevated serum beta-HCG levels would indicate pregnancy, which the patient denied. Adrenal tumor on abdominal MRI or intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI would not typically present with the symptoms described by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s high luteinizing hormone levels and total testosterone levels suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is often associated with irregular menstrual bleeding. Enlarged ovaries on transvaginal ultrasound are commonly seen in PCOS. Elevated serum beta-HCG levels suggest pregnancy or a related condition, adrenal tumor on abdominal MRI is unlikely given the patient’s symptoms, and intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI suggests a pituitary adenoma which is not related to the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has irregular menstrual bleeding, elevated luteinizing hormone, and elevated total testosterone which are indicative of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Enlarged ovaries can be seen on transvaginal ultrasound in patients with PCOS. Elevated serum beta-HCG level indicates pregnancy or a tumor that secretes beta-HCG. An adrenal tumor on abdominal MRI or a mass in the sella turcica on cranial contrast MRI are not associated with PCOS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which is characterized by enlarged ovaries with multiple small cysts. None of the options suggest an intrasellar mass, adrenal tumor, or elevated beta-HCG level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s irregular menstrual bleeding, elevated LH levels, and elevated testosterone suggest a diagnosis of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Enlarged ovaries on transvaginal ultrasound are a characteristic finding in PCOS. Elevated beta-HCG levels suggest pregnancy, an adrenal tumor would be seen on an abdominal CT scan rather than MRI, and an intrasellar mass would be seen on a pituitary MRI, not cranial contrast MRI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has irregular menstrual bleeding and elevated luteinizing hormone and testosterone levels, indicating polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Transvaginal ultrasound may reveal enlarged ovaries with multiple small cysts. None of the other options are associated with PCOS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is commonly associated with enlarged ovaries. Elevated serum beta-HCG level is not expected since the patient is not sexually active. An adrenal tumor is not expected to cause the elevated luteinizing hormone and testosterone levels. An intrasellar mass is not expected in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), including irregular menstrual bleeding, high LH levels, and elevated total testosterone levels. Elevated glucose and insulin levels are also common in PCOS. Enlarged ovaries with numerous small cysts are a characteristic finding on transvaginal ultrasound in PCOS. Elevated HCG levels suggest pregnancy, while adrenal tumors and intrasellar masses are not commonly associated with PCOS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's menstrual history and lab values suggest polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is associated with enlarged ovaries. Elevated serum beta-HCG level is indicative of pregnancy, adrenal tumors are not typically associated with PCOS, and an intrasellar mass on cranial contrast MRI would indicate a pituitary adenoma or other brain lesion, which is not a common finding in PCOS.
